 473        re.MULTILINE,
 474    )
 475    _key_val_dict_pat = re.compile(
 476        r"^([^:\n]+)[ \t]*:[ \t]*([^\n]*)(?:((?:\n[ \t]+[^\n]+)+))?", re.MULTILINE
 477    )  # grp0: key, grp1: value, grp2: multiline value
 478    _meta_data_fence_pattern = re.compile(r'^---[\ \t]*\n', re.MULTILINE)
 479    _meta_data_newline = re.compile("^\n", re.MULTILINE)
 480
 481    def _extract_metadata(self, text):
 482        if text.startswith("---"):
 483            fence_splits = re.split(self._meta_data_fence_pattern, text, maxsplit=2)
 484            metadata_content = fence_splits[1]
 485            match = re.findall(self._meta_data_pattern, metadata_content)
 486            if not match:
 487                return text
 488            tail = fence_splits[2]
 489        else:
 490            metadata_split = re.split(self._meta_data_newline, text, maxsplit=1)
 491            metadata_content = metadata_split[0]
 492            match = re.findall(self._meta_data_pattern, metadata_content)
 493            if not match:
 494                return text
 495            tail = metadata_split[1]
 496
 497        def parse_structured_value(value):
 498            vs = value.lstrip()
 499            vs = value.replace(v[: len(value) - len(vs)], "\n")[1:]
 500
 501            # List
 502            if vs.startswith("-"):
 503                r = []
 504                for match in re.findall(self._key_val_list_pat, vs):
 505                    if match[0] and not match[1] and not match[2]:
 506                        r.append(match[0].strip())
 507                    elif match[0] == ">" and not match[1] and match[2]:
 508                        r.append(match[2].strip())
 509                    elif match[0] and match[1]:
 510                        r.append({match[0].strip(): match[1].strip()})
 511                    elif not match[0] and not match[1] and match[2]:
 512                        r.append(parse_structured_value(match[2]))
 513                    else:
 514                        # Broken case
 515                        pass
 516
 517                return r
 518
 519            # Dict
 520            else:
 521                return {
 522                    match[0].strip(): (
 523                        match[1].strip()
 524                        if match[1]
 525                        else parse_structured_value(match[2])
 526                    )
 527                    for match in re.findall(self._key_val_dict_pat, vs)
 528                }
 529
 530        for item in match:
 531
 532            k, v = item.split(":", 1)
 533
 534            # Multiline value
 535            if v[:3] == " >\n":
 536                self.metadata[k.strip()] = _dedent(v[3:]).strip()
 537
 538            # Empty value
 539            elif v == "\n":
 540                self.metadata[k.strip()] = ""
 541
 542            # Structured value
 543            elif v[0] == "\n":
 544                self.metadata[k.strip()] = parse_structured_value(v)
 545
 546            # Simple value
 547            else:
 548                self.metadata[k.strip()] = v.strip()
 549
 550        return tail
 551
 552    _emacs_oneliner_vars_pat = re.compile(r"((?:<!--)?\s*-\*-)\s*(?:(\S[^\r\n]*?)([\r\n]\s*)?)?(-\*-\s*(?:-->)?)", re.UNICODE)
 553    # This regular expression is intended to match blocks like this:
 554    #    PREFIX Local Variables: SUFFIX
 555    #    PREFIX mode: Tcl SUFFIX
 556    #    PREFIX End: SUFFIX
 557    # Some notes:
 558    # - "[ \t]" is used instead of "\s" to specifically exclude newlines
 559    # - "(\r\n|\n|\r)" is used instead of "$" because the sre engine does
 560    #   not like anything other than Unix-style line terminators.
 561    _emacs_local_vars_pat = re.compile(r"""^
 562        (?P<prefix>(?:[^\r\n|\n|\r])*?)
 563        [\ \t]*Local\ Variables:[\ \t]*
 564        (?P<suffix>.*?)(?:\r\n|\n|\r)
 565        (?P<content>.*?\1End:)
 566        """, re.IGNORECASE | re.MULTILINE | re.DOTALL | re.VERBOSE)
 567
 568    def _emacs_vars_oneliner_sub(self, match):
 569        if match.group(1).strip() == '-*-' and match.group(4).strip() == '-*-':
 570            lead_ws = re.findall(r'^\s*', match.group(1))[0]
 571            tail_ws = re.findall(r'\s*$', match.group(4))[0]
 572            return '%s<!-- %s %s %s -->%s' % (lead_ws, '-*-', match.group(2).strip(), '-*-', tail_ws)
 573
 574        start, end = match.span()
 575        return match.string[start: end]
 576
 577    def _get_emacs_vars(self, text):
 578        """Return a dictionary of emacs-style local variables.
 579
 580        Parsing is done loosely according to this spec (and according to
 581        some in-practice deviations from this):
 582        http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Specifying-File-Variables.html#Specifying-File-Variables
 583        """
 584        emacs_vars = {}
 585        SIZE = pow(2, 13)  # 8kB
 586
 587        # Search near the start for a '-*-'-style one-liner of variables.
 588        head = text[:SIZE]
 589        if "-*-" in head:
 590            match = self._emacs_oneliner_vars_pat.search(head)
 591            if match:
 592                emacs_vars_str = match.group(2)
 593                assert '\n' not in emacs_vars_str
 594                emacs_var_strs = [s.strip() for s in emacs_vars_str.split(';')
 595                                  if s.strip()]
 596                if len(emacs_var_strs) == 1 and ':' not in emacs_var_strs[0]:
 597                    # While not in the spec, this form is allowed by emacs:
 598                    #   -*- Tcl -*-
 599                    # where the implied "variable" is "mode". This form
 600                    # is only allowed if there are no other variables.
 601                    emacs_vars["mode"] = emacs_var_strs[0].strip()
 602                else:
 603                    for emacs_var_str in emacs_var_strs:
 604                        try:
 605                            variable, value = emacs_var_str.strip().split(':', 1)
 606                        except ValueError:
 607                            log.debug("emacs variables error: malformed -*- "
 608                                      "line: %r", emacs_var_str)
 609                            continue
 610                        # Lowercase the variable name because Emacs allows "Mode"
 611                        # or "mode" or "MoDe", etc.
 612                        emacs_vars[variable.lower()] = value.strip()
 613
 614        tail = text[-SIZE:]
 615        if "Local Variables" in tail:
 616            match = self._emacs_local_vars_pat.search(tail)
 617            if match:
 618                prefix = match.group("prefix")
 619                suffix = match.group("suffix")
 620                lines = match.group("content").splitlines(0)
 621                # print "prefix=%r, suffix=%r, content=%r, lines: %s"\
 622                #      % (prefix, suffix, match.group("content"), lines)
 623
 624                # Validate the Local Variables block: proper prefix and suffix
 625                # usage.
 626                for i, line in enumerate(lines):
 627                    if not line.startswith(prefix):
 628                        log.debug("emacs variables error: line '%s' "
 629                                  "does not use proper prefix '%s'"
 630                                  % (line, prefix))
 631                        return {}
 632                    # Don't validate suffix on last line. Emacs doesn't care,
 633                    # neither should we.
 634                    if i != len(lines)-1 and not line.endswith(suffix):
 635                        log.debug("emacs variables error: line '%s' "
 636                                  "does not use proper suffix '%s'"
 637                                  % (line, suffix))
 638                        return {}
 639
 640                # Parse out one emacs var per line.
 641                continued_for = None
 642                for line in lines[:-1]:  # no var on the last line ("PREFIX End:")
 643                    if prefix: line = line[len(prefix):]  # strip prefix
 644                    if suffix: line = line[:-len(suffix)]  # strip suffix
 645                    line = line.strip()
 646                    if continued_for:
 647                        variable = continued_for
 648                        if line.endswith('\\'):
 649                            line = line[:-1].rstrip()
 650                        else:
 651                            continued_for = None
 652                        emacs_vars[variable] += ' ' + line
 653                    else:
 654                        try:
 655                            variable, value = line.split(':', 1)
 656                        except ValueError:
 657                            log.debug("local variables error: missing colon "
 658                                      "in local variables entry: '%s'" % line)
 659                            continue
 660                        # Do NOT lowercase the variable name, because Emacs only
 661                        # allows "mode" (and not "Mode", "MoDe", etc.) in this block.
 662                        value = value.strip()
 663                        if value.endswith('\\'):
 664                            value = value[:-1].rstrip()
 665                            continued_for = variable
 666                        else:
 667                            continued_for = None
 668                        emacs_vars[variable] = value
 669
 670        # Unquote values.
 671        for var, val in list(emacs_vars.items()):
 672            if len(val) > 1 and (val.startswith('"') and val.endswith('"')
 673               or val.startswith('"') and val.endswith('"')):
 674                emacs_vars[var] = val[1:-1]
 675
 676        return emacs_vars
 677
 678    def _detab_line(self, line):
 679        r"""Recusively convert tabs to spaces in a single line.
 680
 681        Called from _detab()."""
 682        if '\t' not in line:
 683            return line
 684        chunk1, chunk2 = line.split('\t', 1)
 685        chunk1 += (' ' * (self.tab_width - len(chunk1) % self.tab_width))
 686        output = chunk1 + chunk2
 687        return self._detab_line(output)
 688
 689    def _detab(self, text):
 690        r"""Iterate text line by line and convert tabs to spaces.
 691
 692            >>> m = Markdown()
 693            >>> m._detab("\tfoo")
 694            '    foo'
 695            >>> m._detab("  \tfoo")
 696            '    foo'
 697            >>> m._detab("\t  foo")
 698            '      foo'
 699            >>> m._detab("  foo")
 700            '  foo'
 701            >>> m._detab("  foo\n\tbar\tblam")
 702            '  foo\n    bar blam'
 703        """
 704        if '\t' not in text:
 705            return text
 706        output = []
 707        for line in text.splitlines():
 708            output.append(self._detab_line(line))
 709        return '\n'.join(output)
 710
 711    # I broke out the html5 tags here and add them to _block_tags_a and
 712    # _block_tags_b.  This way html5 tags are easy to keep track of.
 713    _html5tags = '|article|aside|header|hgroup|footer|nav|section|figure|figcaption'
 714
 715    _block_tags_a = 'p|div|h[1-6]|blockquote|pre|table|dl|ol|ul|script|noscript|form|fieldset|iframe|math|ins|del'
 716    _block_tags_a += _html5tags
 717
 718    _strict_tag_block_re = re.compile(r"""
 719        (                       # save in \1
 720            ^                   # start of line  (with re.M)
 721            <(%s)               # start tag = \2
 722            \b                  # word break
 723            (.*\n)*?            # any number of lines, minimally matching
 724            </\2>               # the matching end tag
 725            [ \t]*              # trailing spaces/tabs
 726            (?=\n+|\Z)          # followed by a newline or end of document
 727        )
 728        """ % _block_tags_a,
 729        re.X | re.M)
 730
 731    _block_tags_b = 'p|div|h[1-6]|blockquote|pre|table|dl|ol|ul|script|noscript|form|fieldset|iframe|math'
 732    _block_tags_b += _html5tags
 733
 734    _liberal_tag_block_re = re.compile(r"""
 735        (                       # save in \1
 736            ^                   # start of line  (with re.M)
 737            <(%s)               # start tag = \2
 738            \b                  # word break
 739            (.*\n)*?            # any number of lines, minimally matching
 740            .*</\2>             # the matching end tag
 741            [ \t]*              # trailing spaces/tabs
 742            (?=\n+|\Z)          # followed by a newline or end of document
 743        )
 744        """ % _block_tags_b,
 745        re.X | re.M)
 746
 747    _html_markdown_attr_re = re.compile(
 748        r'''\s+markdown=("1"|'1')''')
 749    def _hash_html_block_sub(self, match, raw=False):
 750        if isinstance(match, str):
 751            html = match
 752        else:
 753            html = match.group(1)
 754
 755        if raw and self.safe_mode:
 756            html = self._sanitize_html(html)
 757        elif 'markdown-in-html' in self.extras and 'markdown=' in html:
 758            first_line = html.split('\n', 1)[0]
 759            m = self._html_markdown_attr_re.search(first_line)
 760            if m:
 761                lines = html.split('\n')
 762                middle = '\n'.join(lines[1:-1])
 763                last_line = lines[-1]
 764                first_line = first_line[:m.start()] + first_line[m.end():]
 765                f_key = _hash_text(first_line)
 766                self.html_blocks[f_key] = first_line
 767                l_key = _hash_text(last_line)
 768                self.html_blocks[l_key] = last_line
 769                return ''.join(["\n\n", f_key,
 770                    "\n\n", middle, "\n\n",
 771                    l_key, "\n\n"])
 772        key = _hash_text(html)
 773        self.html_blocks[key] = html
 774        return "\n\n" + key + "\n\n"
 775
 776    def _hash_html_blocks(self, text, raw=False):
 777        """Hashify HTML blocks
 778
 779        We only want to do this for block-level HTML tags, such as headers,
 780        lists, and tables. That's because we still want to wrap <p>s around
 781        "paragraphs" that are wrapped in non-block-level tags, such as anchors,
 782        phrase emphasis, and spans. The list of tags we're looking for is
 783        hard-coded.
 784
 785        @param raw {boolean} indicates if these are raw HTML blocks in
 786            the original source. It makes a difference in "safe" mode.
 787        """
 788        if '<' not in text:
 789            return text
 790
 791        # Pass `raw` value into our calls to self._hash_html_block_sub.
 792        hash_html_block_sub = _curry(self._hash_html_block_sub, raw=raw)
 793
 794        # First, look for nested blocks, e.g.:
 795        #   <div>
 796        #       <div>
 797        #       tags for inner block must be indented.
 798        #       </div>
 799        #   </div>
 800        #
 801        # The outermost tags must start at the left margin for this to match, and
 802        # the inner nested divs must be indented.
 803        # We need to do this before the next, more liberal match, because the next
 804        # match will start at the first `<div>` and stop at the first `</div>`.
 805        text = self._strict_tag_block_sub(text, self._block_tags_a, hash_html_block_sub)
 806
 807        # Now match more liberally, simply from `\n<tag>` to `</tag>\n`
 808        text = self._liberal_tag_block_re.sub(hash_html_block_sub, text)
 809
 810        # Special case just for <hr />. It was easier to make a special
 811        # case than to make the other regex more complicated.
 812        if "<hr" in text:
 813            _hr_tag_re = _hr_tag_re_from_tab_width(self.tab_width)
 814            text = _hr_tag_re.sub(hash_html_block_sub, text)
 815
 816        # Special case for standalone HTML comments:
 817        if "<!--" in text:
 818            start = 0
 819            while True:
 820                # Delimiters for next comment block.
 821                try:
 822                    start_idx = text.index("<!--", start)
 823                except ValueError:
 824                    break
 825                try:
 826                    end_idx = text.index("-->", start_idx) + 3
 827                except ValueError:
 828                    break
 829
 830                # Start position for next comment block search.
 831                start = end_idx
 832
 833                # Validate whitespace before comment.
 834                if start_idx:
 835                    # - Up to `tab_width - 1` spaces before start_idx.
 836                    for i in range(self.tab_width - 1):
 837                        if text[start_idx - 1] != ' ':
 838                            break
 839                        start_idx -= 1
 840                        if start_idx == 0:
 841                            break
 842                    # - Must be preceded by 2 newlines or hit the start of
 843                    #   the document.
 844                    if start_idx == 0:
 845                        pass
 846                    elif start_idx == 1 and text[0] == '\n':
 847                        start_idx = 0  # to match minute detail of Markdown.pl regex
 848                    elif text[start_idx-2:start_idx] == '\n\n':
 849                        pass
 850                    else:
 851                        break
 852
 853                # Validate whitespace after comment.
 854                # - Any number of spaces and tabs.
 855                while end_idx < len(text):
 856                    if text[end_idx] not in ' \t':
 857                        break
 858                    end_idx += 1
 859                # - Must be following by 2 newlines or hit end of text.
 860                if text[end_idx:end_idx+2] not in ('', '\n', '\n\n'):
 861                    continue
 862
 863                # Escape and hash (must match `_hash_html_block_sub`).
 864                html = text[start_idx:end_idx]
 865                if raw and self.safe_mode:
 866                    html = self._sanitize_html(html)
 867                key = _hash_text(html)
 868                self.html_blocks[key] = html
 869                text = text[:start_idx] + "\n\n" + key + "\n\n" + text[end_idx:]
 870
 871        if "xml" in self.extras:
 872            # Treat XML processing instructions and namespaced one-liner
 873            # tags as if they were block HTML tags. E.g., if standalone
 874            # (i.e. are their own paragraph), the following do not get
 875            # wrapped in a <p> tag:
 876            #    <?foo bar?>
 877            #
 878            #    <xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" href="chapter_1.md"/>
 879            _xml_oneliner_re = _xml_oneliner_re_from_tab_width(self.tab_width)
 880            text = _xml_oneliner_re.sub(hash_html_block_sub, text)
 881
 882        return text
 883
 884    def _strict_tag_block_sub(self, text, html_tags_re, callback):
 885        tag_count = 0
 886        current_tag = html_tags_re
 887        block = ''
 888        result = ''
 889
 890        for chunk in text.splitlines(True):
 891            is_markup = re.match(r'^(?:</code>(?=</pre>))?(</?(%s)\b>?)' % current_tag, chunk)
 892            block += chunk
 893
 894            if is_markup:
 895                if chunk.startswith('</'):
 896                    tag_count -= 1
 897                else:
 898                    # if close tag is in same line
 899                    if '</%s>' % is_markup.group(2) in chunk[is_markup.end():]:
 900                        # we must ignore these
 901                        is_markup = None
 902                    else:
 903                        tag_count += 1
 904                        current_tag = is_markup.group(2)
 905
 906            if tag_count == 0:
 907                if is_markup:
 908                    block = callback(block.rstrip('\n'))  # remove trailing newline
 909                current_tag = html_tags_re
 910                result += block
 911                block = ''
 912
 913        result += block
 914
 915        return result
 916
 917    def _strip_link_definitions(self, text):
 918        # Strips link definitions from text, stores the URLs and titles in
 919        # hash references.
 920        less_than_tab = self.tab_width - 1
 921
 922        # Link defs are in the form:
 923        #   [id]: url "optional title"
 924        _link_def_re = re.compile(r"""
 925            ^[ ]{0,%d}\[(.+)\]: # id = \1
 926              [ \t]*
 927              \n?               # maybe *one* newline
 928              [ \t]*
 929            <?(.+?)>?           # url = \2
 930              [ \t]*
 931            (?:
 932                \n?             # maybe one newline
 933                [ \t]*
 934                (?<=\s)         # lookbehind for whitespace
 935                ['"(]
 936                ([^\n]*)        # title = \3
 937                ['")]
 938                [ \t]*
 939            )?  # title is optional
 940            (?:\n+|\Z)
 941            """ % less_than_tab, re.X | re.M | re.U)
 942        return _link_def_re.sub(self._extract_link_def_sub, text)
 943
 944    def _extract_link_def_sub(self, match):
 945        id, url, title = match.groups()
 946        key = id.lower()    # Link IDs are case-insensitive
 947        self.urls[key] = self._encode_amps_and_angles(url)
 948        if title:
 949            self.titles[key] = title
 950        return ""
 951
 952    def _do_numbering(self, text):
 953        ''' We handle the special extension for generic numbering for
 954            tables, figures etc.
 955        '''
 956        # First pass to define all the references
 957        self.regex_defns = re.compile(r'''
 958            \[\#(\w+) # the counter.  Open square plus hash plus a word \1
 959            ([^@]*)   # Some optional characters, that aren't an @. \2
 960            @(\w+)       # the id.  Should this be normed? \3
 961            ([^\]]*)\]   # The rest of the text up to the terminating ] \4
 962            ''', re.VERBOSE)
 963        self.regex_subs = re.compile(r"\[@(\w+)\s*\]")  # [@ref_id]
 964        counters = {}
 965        references = {}
 966        replacements = []
 967        definition_html = '<figcaption class="{}" id="counter-ref-{}">{}{}{}</figcaption>'
 968        reference_html = '<a class="{}" href="#counter-ref-{}">{}</a>'
 969        for match in self.regex_defns.finditer(text):
 970            # We must have four match groups otherwise this isn't a numbering reference
 971            if len(match.groups()) != 4:
 972                continue
 973            counter = match.group(1)
 974            text_before = match.group(2).strip()
 975            ref_id = match.group(3)
 976            text_after = match.group(4)
 977            number = counters.get(counter, 1)
 978            references[ref_id] = (number, counter)
 979            replacements.append((match.start(0),
 980                                 definition_html.format(counter,
 981                                                        ref_id,
 982                                                        text_before,
 983                                                        number,
 984                                                        text_after),
 985                                 match.end(0)))
 986            counters[counter] = number + 1
 987        for repl in reversed(replacements):
 988            text = text[:repl[0]] + repl[1] + text[repl[2]:]
 989
 990        # Second pass to replace the references with the right
 991        # value of the counter
 992        # Fwiw, it's vaguely annoying to have to turn the iterator into
 993        # a list and then reverse it but I can't think of a better thing to do.
 994        for match in reversed(list(self.regex_subs.finditer(text))):
 995            number, counter = references.get(match.group(1), (None, None))
 996            if number is not None:
 997                repl = reference_html.format(counter,
 998                                             match.group(1),
 999                                             number)
1000            else:
1001                repl = reference_html.format(match.group(1),
1002                                             'countererror',
1003                                             '?' + match.group(1) + '?')
1004            if "smarty-pants" in self.extras:
1005                repl = repl.replace('"', self._escape_table['"'])
1006
1007            text = text[:match.start()] + repl + text[match.end():]
1008        return text
1009
1010    def _extract_footnote_def_sub(self, match):
1011        id, text = match.groups()
1012        text = _dedent(text, skip_first_line=not text.startswith('\n')).strip()
1013        normed_id = re.sub(r'\W', '-', id)
1014        # Ensure footnote text ends with a couple newlines (for some
1015        # block gamut matches).
1016        self.footnotes[normed_id] = text + "\n\n"
1017        return ""
1018
1019    def _strip_footnote_definitions(self, text):
1020        """A footnote definition looks like this:
1021
1022            [^note-id]: Text of the note.
1023
1024                May include one or more indented paragraphs.
1025
1026        Where,
1027        - The 'note-id' can be pretty much anything, though typically it
1028          is the number of the footnote.
1029        - The first paragraph may start on the next line, like so:
1030
1031            [^note-id]:
1032                Text of the note.
1033        """
1034        less_than_tab = self.tab_width - 1
1035        footnote_def_re = re.compile(r'''
1036            ^[ ]{0,%d}\[\^(.+)\]:   # id = \1
1037            [ \t]*
1038            (                       # footnote text = \2
1039              # First line need not start with the spaces.
1040              (?:\s*.*\n+)
1041              (?:
1042                (?:[ ]{%d} | \t)  # Subsequent lines must be indented.
1043                .*\n+
1044              )*
1045            )
1046            # Lookahead for non-space at line-start, or end of doc.
1047            (?:(?=^[ ]{0,%d}\S)|\Z)
1048            ''' % (less_than_tab, self.tab_width, self.tab_width),
1049            re.X | re.M)
1050        return footnote_def_re.sub(self._extract_footnote_def_sub, text)
1051
1052    _hr_re = re.compile(r'^[ ]{0,3}([-_*])[ ]{0,2}(\1[ ]{0,2}){2,}$', re.M)
1053
1054    def _run_block_gamut(self, text):
1055        # These are all the transformations that form block-level
1056        # tags like paragraphs, headers, and list items.
1057
1058        if 'admonitions' in self.extras:
1059            text = self._do_admonitions(text)
1060
1061        if 'wavedrom' in self.extras:
1062            text = self._do_wavedrom_blocks(text)
1063
1064        if "fenced-code-blocks" in self.extras:
1065            text = self._do_fenced_code_blocks(text)
1066
1067        text = self._do_headers(text)
1068
1069        # Do Horizontal Rules:
1070        # On the number of spaces in horizontal rules: The spec is fuzzy: "If
1071        # you wish, you may use spaces between the hyphens or asterisks."
1072        # Markdown.pl 1.0.1's hr regexes limit the number of spaces between the
1073        # hr chars to one or two. We'll reproduce that limit here.
1074        hr = "\n<hr"+self.empty_element_suffix+"\n"
1075        text = re.sub(self._hr_re, hr, text)
1076
1077        text = self._do_lists(text)
1078
1079        if "pyshell" in self.extras:
1080            text = self._prepare_pyshell_blocks(text)
1081        if "wiki-tables" in self.extras:
1082            text = self._do_wiki_tables(text)
1083        if "tables" in self.extras:
1084            text = self._do_tables(text)
1085
1086        text = self._do_code_blocks(text)
1087
1088        text = self._do_block_quotes(text)
1089
1090        # We already ran _HashHTMLBlocks() before, in Markdown(), but that
1091        # was to escape raw HTML in the original Markdown source. This time,
1092        # we're escaping the markup we've just created, so that we don't wrap
1093        # <p> tags around block-level tags.
1094        text = self._hash_html_blocks(text)
1095
1096        text = self._form_paragraphs(text)
1097
1098        return text
1099
1100    def _pyshell_block_sub(self, match):
1101        if "fenced-code-blocks" in self.extras:
1102            dedented = _dedent(match.group(0))
1103            return self._do_fenced_code_blocks("```pycon\n" + dedented + "```\n")
1104        lines = match.group(0).splitlines(0)
1105        _dedentlines(lines)
1106        indent = ' ' * self.tab_width
1107        s = ('\n'  # separate from possible cuddled paragraph
1108             + indent + ('\n'+indent).join(lines)
1109             + '\n')
1110        return s
1111
1112    def _prepare_pyshell_blocks(self, text):
1113        """Ensure that Python interactive shell sessions are put in
1114        code blocks -- even if not properly indented.
1115        """
1116        if ">>>" not in text:
1117            return text
1118
1119        less_than_tab = self.tab_width - 1
1120        _pyshell_block_re = re.compile(r"""
1121            ^([ ]{0,%d})>>>[ ].*\n  # first line
1122            ^(\1[^\S\n]*\S.*\n)*    # any number of subsequent lines with at least one character
1123            (?=^\1?\n|\Z)           # ends with a blank line or end of document
1124            """ % less_than_tab, re.M | re.X)
1125
1126        return _pyshell_block_re.sub(self._pyshell_block_sub, text)
1127
1128    def _table_sub(self, match):
1129        trim_space_re = '^[ \t\n]+|[ \t\n]+$'
1130        trim_bar_re = r'^\||\|$'
1131        split_bar_re = r'^\||(?<![\`\\])\|'
1132        escape_bar_re = r'\\\|'
1133
1134        head, underline, body = match.groups()
1135
1136        # Determine aligns for columns.
1137        cols = [re.sub(escape_bar_re, '|', cell.strip()) for cell in re.split(split_bar_re, re.sub(trim_bar_re, "", re.sub(trim_space_re, "", underline)))]
1138        align_from_col_idx = {}
1139        for col_idx, col in enumerate(cols):
1140            if col[0] == ':' and col[-1] == ':':
1141                align_from_col_idx[col_idx] = ' style="text-align:center;"'
1142            elif col[0] == ':':
1143                align_from_col_idx[col_idx] = ' style="text-align:left;"'
1144            elif col[-1] == ':':
1145                align_from_col_idx[col_idx] = ' style="text-align:right;"'
1146
1147        # thead
1148        hlines = ['<table%s>' % self._html_class_str_from_tag('table'), '<thead%s>' % self._html_class_str_from_tag('thead'), '<tr>']
1149        cols = [re.sub(escape_bar_re, '|', cell.strip()) for cell in re.split(split_bar_re, re.sub(trim_bar_re, "", re.sub(trim_space_re, "", head)))]
1150        for col_idx, col in enumerate(cols):
1151            hlines.append('  <th%s>%s</th>' % (
1152                align_from_col_idx.get(col_idx, ''),
1153                self._run_span_gamut(col)
1154            ))
1155        hlines.append('</tr>')
1156        hlines.append('</thead>')
1157
1158        # tbody
1159        hlines.append('<tbody>')
1160        for line in body.strip('\n').split('\n'):
1161            hlines.append('<tr>')
1162            cols = [re.sub(escape_bar_re, '|', cell.strip()) for cell in re.split(split_bar_re, re.sub(trim_bar_re, "", re.sub(trim_space_re, "", line)))]
1163            for col_idx, col in enumerate(cols):
1164                hlines.append('  <td%s>%s</td>' % (
1165                    align_from_col_idx.get(col_idx, ''),
1166                    self._run_span_gamut(col)
1167                ))
1168            hlines.append('</tr>')
1169        hlines.append('</tbody>')
1170        hlines.append('</table>')
1171
1172        return '\n'.join(hlines) + '\n'
1173
1174    def _do_tables(self, text):
1175        """Copying PHP-Markdown and GFM table syntax. Some regex borrowed from
1176        https://github.com/michelf/php-markdown/blob/lib/Michelf/Markdown.php#L2538
1177        """
1178        less_than_tab = self.tab_width - 1
1179        table_re = re.compile(r'''
1180                (?:(?<=\n\n)|\A\n?)             # leading blank line
1181
1182                ^[ ]{0,%d}                      # allowed whitespace
1183                (.*[|].*)  \n                   # $1: header row (at least one pipe)
1184
1185                ^[ ]{0,%d}                      # allowed whitespace
1186                (                               # $2: underline row
1187                    # underline row with leading bar
1188                    (?:  \|\ *:?-+:?\ *  )+  \|? \s? \n
1189                    |
1190                    # or, underline row without leading bar
1191                    (?:  \ *:?-+:?\ *\|  )+  (?:  \ *:?-+:?\ *  )? \s? \n
1192                )
1193
1194                (                               # $3: data rows
1195                    (?:
1196                        ^[ ]{0,%d}(?!\ )         # ensure line begins with 0 to less_than_tab spaces
1197                        .*\|.*  \n
1198                    )+
1199                )
1200            ''' % (less_than_tab, less_than_tab, less_than_tab), re.M | re.X)
1201        return table_re.sub(self._table_sub, text)
1202
1203    def _wiki_table_sub(self, match):
1204        ttext = match.group(0).strip()
1205        # print('wiki table: %r' % match.group(0))
1206        rows = []
1207        for line in ttext.splitlines(0):
1208            line = line.strip()[2:-2].strip()
1209            row = [c.strip() for c in re.split(r'(?<!\\)\|\|', line)]
1210            rows.append(row)
1211        # from pprint import pprint
1212        # pprint(rows)
1213        hlines = []
1214
1215        def add_hline(line, indents=0):
1216            hlines.append((self.tab * indents) + line)
1217
1218        def format_cell(text):
1219            return self._run_span_gamut(re.sub(r"^\s*~", "", cell).strip(" "))
1220
1221        add_hline('<table%s>' % self._html_class_str_from_tag('table'))
1222        # Check if first cell of first row is a header cell. If so, assume the whole row is a header row.
1223        if rows and rows[0] and re.match(r"^\s*~", rows[0][0]):
1224            add_hline('<thead%s>' % self._html_class_str_from_tag('thead'), 1)
1225            add_hline('<tr>', 2)
1226            for cell in rows[0]:
1227                add_hline("<th>{}</th>".format(format_cell(cell)), 3)
1228            add_hline('</tr>', 2)
1229            add_hline('</thead>', 1)
1230            # Only one header row allowed.
1231            rows = rows[1:]
1232        # If no more rows, don't create a tbody.
1233        if rows:
1234            add_hline('<tbody>', 1)
1235            for row in rows:
1236                add_hline('<tr>', 2)
1237                for cell in row:
1238                    add_hline('<td>{}</td>'.format(format_cell(cell)), 3)
1239                add_hline('</tr>', 2)
1240            add_hline('</tbody>', 1)
1241        add_hline('</table>')
1242        return '\n'.join(hlines) + '\n'
1243
1244    def _do_wiki_tables(self, text):
1245        # Optimization.
1246        if "||" not in text:
1247            return text
1248
1249        less_than_tab = self.tab_width - 1
1250        wiki_table_re = re.compile(r'''
1251            (?:(?<=\n\n)|\A\n?)            # leading blank line
1252            ^([ ]{0,%d})\|\|.+?\|\|[ ]*\n  # first line
1253            (^\1\|\|.+?\|\|\n)*        # any number of subsequent lines
1254            ''' % less_than_tab, re.M | re.X)
1255        return wiki_table_re.sub(self._wiki_table_sub, text)
1256
1257    def _run_span_gamut(self, text):
1258        # These are all the transformations that occur *within* block-level
1259        # tags like paragraphs, headers, and list items.
1260
1261        text = self._do_code_spans(text)
1262
1263        text = self._escape_special_chars(text)
1264
1265        # Process anchor and image tags.
1266        if "link-patterns" in self.extras:
1267            text = self._do_link_patterns(text)
1268
1269        text = self._do_links(text)
1270
1271        # Make links out of things like `<http://example.com/>`
1272        # Must come after _do_links(), because you can use < and >
1273        # delimiters in inline links like [this](<url>).
1274        text = self._do_auto_links(text)
1275
1276        text = self._encode_amps_and_angles(text)
1277
1278        if "strike" in self.extras:
1279            text = self._do_strike(text)
1280
1281        if "underline" in self.extras:
1282            text = self._do_underline(text)
1283
1284        text = self._do_italics_and_bold(text)
1285
1286        if "tg-spoiler" in self.extras:
1287            text = self._do_tg_spoiler(text)
1288
1289        if "smarty-pants" in self.extras:
1290            text = self._do_smart_punctuation(text)
1291
1292        # Do hard breaks:
1293        if "break-on-newline" in self.extras:
1294            text = re.sub(r" *\n(?!\<(?:\/?(ul|ol|li))\>)", "<br%s\n" % self.empty_element_suffix, text)
1295        else:
1296            text = re.sub(r" {2,}\n", " <br%s\n" % self.empty_element_suffix, text)
1297
1298        return text
1299
1300    # "Sorta" because auto-links are identified as "tag" tokens.
1301    _sorta_html_tokenize_re = re.compile(r"""
1302        (
1303            \\*  # escapes
1304            (?:
1305                # tag
1306                </?
1307                (?:\w+)                                     # tag name
1308                (?:\s+(?:[\w-]+:)?[\w-]+=(?:".*?"|'.*?'))*  # attributes
1309                \s*/?>
1310                |
1311                # auto-link (e.g., <http://www.activestate.com/>)
1312                <[\w~:/?#\[\]@!$&'\(\)*+,;%=\.\\-]+>
1313                |
1314                <!--.*?-->      # comment
1315                |
1316                <\?.*?\?>       # processing instruction
1317            )
1318        )
1319        """, re.X)
1320
1321    def _escape_special_chars(self, text):
1322        # Python markdown note: the HTML tokenization here differs from
1323        # that in Markdown.pl, hence the behaviour for subtle cases can
1324        # differ (I believe the tokenizer here does a better job because
1325        # it isn't susceptible to unmatched '<' and '>' in HTML tags).
1326        # Note, however, that '>' is not allowed in an auto-link URL
1327        # here.
1328        lead_escape_re = re.compile(r'^((?:\\\\)*(?!\\))')
1329        escaped = []
1330        is_html_markup = False
1331        for token in self._sorta_html_tokenize_re.split(text):
1332            # check token is preceded by 0 or more PAIRS of escapes, because escape pairs
1333            # escape themselves and don't affect the token
1334            if is_html_markup and lead_escape_re.match(token):
1335                # Within tags/HTML-comments/auto-links, encode * and _
1336                # so they don't conflict with their use in Markdown for
1337                # italics and strong.  We're replacing each such
1338                # character with its corresponding MD5 checksum value;
1339                # this is likely overkill, but it should prevent us from
1340                # colliding with the escape values by accident.
1341                escape_seq, token = lead_escape_re.split(token)[1:] or ('', token)
1342                escaped.append(
1343                    escape_seq.replace('\\\\', self._escape_table['\\'])
1344                    + token.replace('*', self._escape_table['*'])
1345                           .replace('_', self._escape_table['_'])
1346                )
1347            else:
1348                escaped.append(self._encode_backslash_escapes(token.replace('\\<', '&lt;')))
1349            is_html_markup = not is_html_markup
1350        return ''.join(escaped)
1351
1352    def _hash_html_spans(self, text):
1353        # Used for safe_mode.
1354
1355        def _is_auto_link(s):
1356            if ':' in s and self._auto_link_re.match(s):
1357                return True
1358            elif '@' in s and self._auto_email_link_re.match(s):
1359                return True
1360            return False
1361
1362        def _is_code_span(index, token):
1363            try:
1364                if token == '<code>':
1365                    peek_tokens = split_tokens[index: index + 3]
1366                elif token == '</code>':
1367                    peek_tokens = split_tokens[index - 2: index + 1]
1368                else:
1369                    return False
1370            except IndexError:
1371                return False
1372
1373            return re.match(r'<code>md5-[A-Fa-f0-9]{32}</code>', ''.join(peek_tokens))
1374
1375        tokens = []
1376        split_tokens = self._sorta_html_tokenize_re.split(text)
1377        is_html_markup = False
1378        for index, token in enumerate(split_tokens):
1379            if is_html_markup and not _is_auto_link(token) and not _is_code_span(index, token):
1380                sanitized = self._sanitize_html(token)
1381                key = _hash_text(sanitized)
1382                self.html_spans[key] = sanitized
1383                tokens.append(key)
1384            else:
1385                tokens.append(self._encode_incomplete_tags(token))
1386            is_html_markup = not is_html_markup
1387        return ''.join(tokens)
1388
1389    def _unhash_html_spans(self, text):
1390        for key, sanitized in list(self.html_spans.items()):
1391            text = text.replace(key, sanitized)
1392        return text
1393
1394    def _sanitize_html(self, s):
1395        if self.safe_mode == "replace":
1396            return self.html_removed_text
1397        elif self.safe_mode == "escape":
1398            replacements = [
1399                ('&', '&amp;'),
1400                ('<', '&lt;'),
1401                ('>', '&gt;'),
1402            ]
1403            for before, after in replacements:
1404                s = s.replace(before, after)
1405            return s
1406        else:
1407            raise MarkdownError("invalid value for 'safe_mode': %r (must be "
1408                                "'escape' or 'replace')" % self.safe_mode)
1409
1410    _inline_link_title = re.compile(r'''
1411            (                   # \1
1412              [ \t]+
1413              (['"])            # quote char = \2
1414              (?P<title>.*?)
1415              \2
1416            )?                  # title is optional
1417          \)$
1418        ''', re.X | re.S)
1419    _tail_of_reference_link_re = re.compile(r'''
1420          # Match tail of: [text][id]
1421          [ ]?          # one optional space
1422          (?:\n[ ]*)?   # one optional newline followed by spaces
1423          \[
1424            (?P<id>.*?)
1425          \]
1426        ''', re.X | re.S)
1427
1428    _whitespace = re.compile(r'\s*')
1429
1430    _strip_anglebrackets = re.compile(r'<(.*)>.*')
1431
1432    def _find_non_whitespace(self, text, start):
1433        """Returns the index of the first non-whitespace character in text
1434        after (and including) start
1435        """
1436        match = self._whitespace.match(text, start)
1437        return match.end()
1438
1439    def _find_balanced(self, text, start, open_c, close_c):
1440        """Returns the index where the open_c and close_c characters balance
1441        out - the same number of open_c and close_c are encountered - or the
1442        end of string if it's reached before the balance point is found.
1443        """
1444        i = start
1445        l = len(text)
1446        count = 1
1447        while count > 0 and i < l:
1448            if text[i] == open_c:
1449                count += 1
1450            elif text[i] == close_c:
1451                count -= 1
1452            i += 1
1453        return i
1454
1455    def _extract_url_and_title(self, text, start):
1456        """Extracts the url and (optional) title from the tail of a link"""
1457        # text[start] equals the opening parenthesis
1458        idx = self._find_non_whitespace(text, start+1)
1459        if idx == len(text):
1460            return None, None, None
1461        end_idx = idx
1462        has_anglebrackets = text[idx] == "<"
1463        if has_anglebrackets:
1464            end_idx = self._find_balanced(text, end_idx+1, "<", ">")
1465        end_idx = self._find_balanced(text, end_idx, "(", ")")
1466        match = self._inline_link_title.search(text, idx, end_idx)
1467        if not match:
1468            return None, None, None
1469        url, title = text[idx:match.start()], match.group("title")
1470        if has_anglebrackets:
1471            url = self._strip_anglebrackets.sub(r'\1', url)
1472        return url, title, end_idx
1473
1474    def _protect_url(self, url):
1475        '''
1476        Function that passes a URL through `_html_escape_url` to remove any nasty characters,
1477        and then hashes the now "safe" URL to prevent other safety mechanisms from tampering
1478        with it (eg: escaping "&" in URL parameters)
1479        '''
1480        url = _html_escape_url(url, safe_mode=self.safe_mode)
1481        key = _hash_text(url)
1482        self._escape_table[url] = key
1483        return key
1484
1485    _safe_protocols = re.compile(r'(https?|ftp):', re.I)
1486    def _do_links(self, text):
1487        """Turn Markdown link shortcuts into XHTML <a> and <img> tags.
1488
1489        This is a combination of Markdown.pl's _DoAnchors() and
1490        _DoImages(). They are done together because that simplified the
1491        approach. It was necessary to use a different approach than
1492        Markdown.pl because of the lack of atomic matching support in
1493        Python's regex engine used in $g_nested_brackets.
1494        """
1495        MAX_LINK_TEXT_SENTINEL = 3000  # markdown2 issue 24
1496
1497        # `anchor_allowed_pos` is used to support img links inside
1498        # anchors, but not anchors inside anchors. An anchor's start
1499        # pos must be `>= anchor_allowed_pos`.
1500        anchor_allowed_pos = 0
1501
1502        curr_pos = 0
1503        while True:  # Handle the next link.
1504            # The next '[' is the start of:
1505            # - an inline anchor:   [text](url "title")
1506            # - a reference anchor: [text][id]
1507            # - an inline img:      ![text](url "title")
1508            # - a reference img:    ![text][id]
1509            # - a footnote ref:     [^id]
1510            #   (Only if 'footnotes' extra enabled)
1511            # - a footnote defn:    [^id]: ...
1512            #   (Only if 'footnotes' extra enabled) These have already
1513            #   been stripped in _strip_footnote_definitions() so no
1514            #   need to watch for them.
1515            # - a link definition:  [id]: url "title"
1516            #   These have already been stripped in
1517            #   _strip_link_definitions() so no need to watch for them.
1518            # - not markup:         [...anything else...
1519            try:
1520                start_idx = text.index('[', curr_pos)
1521            except ValueError:
1522                break
1523            text_length = len(text)
1524
1525            # Find the matching closing ']'.
1526            # Markdown.pl allows *matching* brackets in link text so we
1527            # will here too. Markdown.pl *doesn't* currently allow
1528            # matching brackets in img alt text -- we'll differ in that
1529            # regard.
1530            bracket_depth = 0
1531            for p in range(start_idx+1, min(start_idx+MAX_LINK_TEXT_SENTINEL,
1532                                            text_length)):
1533                ch = text[p]
1534                if ch == ']':
1535                    bracket_depth -= 1
1536                    if bracket_depth < 0:
1537                        break
1538                elif ch == '[':
1539                    bracket_depth += 1
1540            else:
1541                # Closing bracket not found within sentinel length.
1542                # This isn't markup.
1543                curr_pos = start_idx + 1
1544                continue
1545            link_text = text[start_idx+1:p]
1546
1547            # Fix for issue 341 - Injecting XSS into link text
1548            if self.safe_mode:
1549                link_text = self._hash_html_spans(link_text)
1550                link_text = self._unhash_html_spans(link_text)
1551
1552            # Possibly a footnote ref?
1553            if "footnotes" in self.extras and link_text.startswith("^"):
1554                normed_id = re.sub(r'\W', '-', link_text[1:])
1555                if normed_id in self.footnotes:
1556                    self.footnote_ids.append(normed_id)
1557                    result = '<sup class="footnote-ref" id="fnref-%s">' \
1558                             '<a href="#fn-%s">%s</a></sup>' \
1559                             % (normed_id, normed_id, len(self.footnote_ids))
1560                    text = text[:start_idx] + result + text[p+1:]
1561                else:
1562                    # This id isn't defined, leave the markup alone.
1563                    curr_pos = p+1
1564                continue
1565
1566            # Now determine what this is by the remainder.
1567            p += 1
1568
1569            # Inline anchor or img?
1570            if text[p:p + 1] == '(':  # attempt at perf improvement
1571                url, title, url_end_idx = self._extract_url_and_title(text, p)
1572                if url is not None:
1573                    # Handle an inline anchor or img.
1574                    is_img = start_idx > 0 and text[start_idx-1] == "!"
1575                    if is_img:
1576                        start_idx -= 1
1577
1578                    # We've got to encode these to avoid conflicting
1579                    # with italics/bold.
1580                    url = url.replace('*', self._escape_table['*']) \
1581                             .replace('_', self._escape_table['_'])
1582                    if title:
1583                        title_str = ' title="%s"' % (
1584                            _xml_escape_attr(title)
1585                                .replace('*', self._escape_table['*'])
1586                                .replace('_', self._escape_table['_']))
1587                    else:
1588                        title_str = ''
1589                    if is_img:
1590                        img_class_str = self._html_class_str_from_tag("img")
1591                        result = '<img src="%s" alt="%s"%s%s%s' \
1592                            % (self._protect_url(url),
1593                               _xml_escape_attr(link_text),
1594                               title_str,
1595                               img_class_str,
1596                               self.empty_element_suffix)
1597                        if "smarty-pants" in self.extras:
1598                            result = result.replace('"', self._escape_table['"'])
1599                        curr_pos = start_idx + len(result)
1600                        anchor_allowed_pos = start_idx + len(result)
1601                        text = text[:start_idx] + result + text[url_end_idx:]
1602                    elif start_idx >= anchor_allowed_pos:
1603                        safe_link = self._safe_protocols.match(url) or url.startswith('#')
1604                        if self.safe_mode and not safe_link:
1605                            result_head = '<a href="#"%s>' % (title_str)
1606                        else:
1607                            result_head = '<a href="%s"%s>' % (self._protect_url(url), title_str)
1608                        result = '%s%s</a>' % (result_head, link_text)
1609                        if "smarty-pants" in self.extras:
1610                            result = result.replace('"', self._escape_table['"'])
1611                        # <img> allowed from curr_pos on, <a> from
1612                        # anchor_allowed_pos on.
1613                        curr_pos = start_idx + len(result_head)
1614                        anchor_allowed_pos = start_idx + len(result)
1615                        text = text[:start_idx] + result + text[url_end_idx:]
1616                    else:
1617                        # Anchor not allowed here.
1618                        curr_pos = start_idx + 1
1619                    continue
1620
1621            # Reference anchor or img?
1622            else:
1623                match = self._tail_of_reference_link_re.match(text, p)
1624                if match:
1625                    # Handle a reference-style anchor or img.
1626                    is_img = start_idx > 0 and text[start_idx-1] == "!"
1627                    if is_img:
1628                        start_idx -= 1
1629                    link_id = match.group("id").lower()
1630                    if not link_id:
1631                        link_id = link_text.lower()  # for links like [this][]
1632                    if link_id in self.urls:
1633                        url = self.urls[link_id]
1634                        # We've got to encode these to avoid conflicting
1635                        # with italics/bold.
1636                        url = url.replace('*', self._escape_table['*']) \
1637                                 .replace('_', self._escape_table['_'])
1638                        title = self.titles.get(link_id)
1639                        if title:
1640                            title = _xml_escape_attr(title) \
1641                                .replace('*', self._escape_table['*']) \
1642                                .replace('_', self._escape_table['_'])
1643                            title_str = ' title="%s"' % title
1644                        else:
1645                            title_str = ''
1646                        if is_img:
1647                            img_class_str = self._html_class_str_from_tag("img")
1648                            result = '<img src="%s" alt="%s"%s%s%s' \
1649                                % (self._protect_url(url),
1650                                   _xml_escape_attr(link_text),
1651                                   title_str,
1652                                   img_class_str,
1653                                   self.empty_element_suffix)
1654                            if "smarty-pants" in self.extras:
1655                                result = result.replace('"', self._escape_table['"'])
1656                            curr_pos = start_idx + len(result)
1657                            text = text[:start_idx] + result + text[match.end():]
1658                        elif start_idx >= anchor_allowed_pos:
1659                            if self.safe_mode and not self._safe_protocols.match(url):
1660                                result_head = '<a href="#"%s>' % (title_str)
1661                            else:
1662                                result_head = '<a href="%s"%s>' % (self._protect_url(url), title_str)
1663                            result = '%s%s</a>' % (result_head, link_text)
1664                            if "smarty-pants" in self.extras:
1665                                result = result.replace('"', self._escape_table['"'])
1666                            # <img> allowed from curr_pos on, <a> from
1667                            # anchor_allowed_pos on.
1668                            curr_pos = start_idx + len(result_head)
1669                            anchor_allowed_pos = start_idx + len(result)
1670                            text = text[:start_idx] + result + text[match.end():]
1671                        else:
1672                            # Anchor not allowed here.
1673                            curr_pos = start_idx + 1
1674                    else:
1675                        # This id isn't defined, leave the markup alone.
1676                        curr_pos = match.end()
1677                    continue
1678
1679            # Otherwise, it isn't markup.
1680            curr_pos = start_idx + 1
1681
1682        return text
1683
1684    def header_id_from_text(self, text, prefix, n):
1685        """Generate a header id attribute value from the given header
1686        HTML content.
1687
1688        This is only called if the "header-ids" extra is enabled.
1689        Subclasses may override this for different header ids.
1690
1691        @param text {str} The text of the header tag
1692        @param prefix {str} The requested prefix for header ids. This is the
1693            value of the "header-ids" extra key, if any. Otherwise, None.
1694        @param n {int} The <hN> tag number, i.e. `1` for an <h1> tag.
1695        @returns {str} The value for the header tag's "id" attribute. Return
1696            None to not have an id attribute and to exclude this header from
1697            the TOC (if the "toc" extra is specified).
1698        """
1699        header_id = _slugify(text)
1700        if prefix and isinstance(prefix, str):
1701            header_id = prefix + '-' + header_id
1702
1703        self._count_from_header_id[header_id] += 1
1704        if 0 == len(header_id) or self._count_from_header_id[header_id] > 1:
1705            header_id += '-%s' % self._count_from_header_id[header_id]
1706
1707        return header_id
1708
1709    def _toc_add_entry(self, level, id, name):
1710        if level > self._toc_depth:
1711            return
1712        if self._toc is None:
1713            self._toc = []
1714        self._toc.append((level, id, self._unescape_special_chars(name)))
1715
1716    _h_re_base = r'''
1717        (^(.+)[ \t]{0,99}\n(=+|-+)[ \t]*\n+)
1718        |
1719        (^(\#{1,6})  # \1 = string of #'s
1720        [ \t]%s
1721        (.+?)       # \2 = Header text
1722        [ \t]{0,99}
1723        (?<!\\)     # ensure not an escaped trailing '#'
1724        \#*         # optional closing #'s (not counted)
1725        \n+
1726        )
1727        '''
1728
1729    _h_re = re.compile(_h_re_base % '*', re.X | re.M)
1730    _h_re_tag_friendly = re.compile(_h_re_base % '+', re.X | re.M)
1731
1732    def _h_sub(self, match):
1733        if match.group(1) is not None and match.group(3) == "-":
1734            return match.group(1)
1735        elif match.group(1) is not None:
1736            # Setext header
1737            n = {"=": 1, "-": 2}[match.group(3)[0]]
1738            header_group = match.group(2)
1739        else:
1740            # atx header
1741            n = len(match.group(5))
1742            header_group = match.group(6)
1743
1744        demote_headers = self.extras.get("demote-headers")
1745        if demote_headers:
1746            n = min(n + demote_headers, 6)
1747        header_id_attr = ""
1748        if "header-ids" in self.extras:
1749            header_id = self.header_id_from_text(header_group,
1750                self.extras["header-ids"], n)
1751            if header_id:
1752                header_id_attr = ' id="%s"' % header_id
1753        html = self._run_span_gamut(header_group)
1754        if "toc" in self.extras and header_id:
1755            self._toc_add_entry(n, header_id, html)
1756        return "<h%d%s>%s</h%d>\n\n" % (n, header_id_attr, html, n)
1757
1758    def _do_headers(self, text):
1759        # Setext-style headers:
1760        #     Header 1
1761        #     ========
1762        #
1763        #     Header 2
1764        #     --------
1765
1766        # atx-style headers:
1767        #   # Header 1
1768        #   ## Header 2
1769        #   ## Header 2 with closing hashes ##
1770        #   ...
1771        #   ###### Header 6
1772
1773        if 'tag-friendly' in self.extras:
1774            return self._h_re_tag_friendly.sub(self._h_sub, text)
1775        return self._h_re.sub(self._h_sub, text)
1776
1777    _marker_ul_chars = '*+-'
1778    _marker_any = r'(?:[%s]|\d+\.)' % _marker_ul_chars
1779    _marker_ul = '(?:[%s])' % _marker_ul_chars
1780    _marker_ol = r'(?:\d+\.)'
1781
1782    def _list_sub(self, match):
1783        lst = match.group(1)
1784        lst_type = match.group(4) in self._marker_ul_chars and "ul" or "ol"
1785
1786        if lst_type == 'ol' and match.group(4) != '1.':
1787            # if list doesn't start at 1 then set the ol start attribute
1788            lst_opts = ' start="%s"' % match.group(4)[:-1]
1789        else:
1790            lst_opts = ''
1791
1792        lst_opts = lst_opts + self._html_class_str_from_tag(lst_type)
1793
1794        result = self._process_list_items(lst)
1795        if self.list_level:
1796            return "<%s%s>\n%s</%s>\n" % (lst_type, lst_opts, result, lst_type)
1797        else:
1798            return "<%s%s>\n%s</%s>\n\n" % (lst_type, lst_opts, result, lst_type)
1799
1800    def _do_lists(self, text):
1801        # Form HTML ordered (numbered) and unordered (bulleted) lists.
1802
1803        # Iterate over each *non-overlapping* list match.
1804        pos = 0
1805        while True:
1806            # Find the *first* hit for either list style (ul or ol). We
1807            # match ul and ol separately to avoid adjacent lists of different
1808            # types running into each other (see issue #16).
1809            hits = []
1810            for marker_pat in (self._marker_ul, self._marker_ol):
1811                less_than_tab = self.tab_width - 1
1812                other_marker_pat = self._marker_ul if marker_pat == self._marker_ol else self._marker_ol
1813                whole_list = r'''
1814                    (                   # \1 = whole list
1815                      (                 # \2
1816                        ([ ]{0,%d})     # \3 = the indentation level of the list item marker
1817                        (%s)            # \4 = first list item marker
1818                        [ \t]+
1819                        (?!\ *\4\ )     # '- - - ...' isn't a list. See 'not_quite_a_list' test case.
1820                      )
1821                      (?:.+?)
1822                      (                 # \5
1823                          \Z
1824                        |
1825                          \n{2,}
1826                          (?=\S)
1827                          (?!           # Negative lookahead for another list item marker
1828                            [ \t]*
1829                            %s[ \t]+
1830                          )
1831                        |
1832                          \n+
1833                          (?=
1834                            \3          # lookahead for a different style of list item marker
1835                            %s[ \t]+
1836                          )
1837                      )
1838                    )
1839                ''' % (less_than_tab, marker_pat, marker_pat, other_marker_pat)
1840                if self.list_level:  # sub-list
1841                    list_re = re.compile("^"+whole_list, re.X | re.M | re.S)
1842                else:
1843                    list_re = re.compile(r"(?:(?<=\n\n)|\A\n?)"+whole_list,
1844                                         re.X | re.M | re.S)
1845                match = list_re.search(text, pos)
1846                if match:
1847                    hits.append((match.start(), match))
1848            if not hits:
1849                break
1850            hits.sort()
1851            match = hits[0][1]
1852            start, end = match.span()
1853            middle = self._list_sub(match)
1854            text = text[:start] + middle + text[end:]
1855            pos = start + len(middle)  # start pos for next attempted match
1856
1857        return text
1858
1859    _list_item_re = re.compile(r'''
1860        (\n)?                   # leading line = \1
1861        (^[ \t]*)               # leading whitespace = \2
1862        (?P<marker>%s) [ \t]+   # list marker = \3
1863        ((?:.+?)                # list item text = \4
1864        (\n{1,2}))              # eols = \5
1865        (?= \n* (\Z | \2 (?P<next_marker>%s) [ \t]+))
1866        ''' % (_marker_any, _marker_any),
1867        re.M | re.X | re.S)
1868
1869    _task_list_item_re = re.compile(r'''
1870        (\[[\ xX]\])[ \t]+       # tasklist marker = \1
1871        (.*)                   # list item text = \2
1872    ''', re.M | re.X | re.S)
1873
1874    _task_list_warpper_str = r'<input type="checkbox" class="task-list-item-checkbox" %sdisabled> %s'
1875
1876    def _task_list_item_sub(self, match):
1877        marker = match.group(1)
1878        item_text = match.group(2)
1879        if marker in ['[x]','[X]']:
1880                return self._task_list_warpper_str % ('checked ', item_text)
1881        elif marker == '[ ]':
1882                return self._task_list_warpper_str % ('', item_text)
1883
1884    _last_li_endswith_two_eols = False
1885    def _list_item_sub(self, match):
1886        item = match.group(4)
1887        leading_line = match.group(1)
1888        if leading_line or "\n\n" in item or self._last_li_endswith_two_eols:
1889            item = self._run_block_gamut(self._outdent(item))
1890        else:
1891            # Recursion for sub-lists:
1892            item = self._do_lists(self._uniform_outdent(item, min_outdent=' ')[1])
1893            if item.endswith('\n'):
1894                item = item[:-1]
1895            item = self._run_span_gamut(item)
1896        self._last_li_endswith_two_eols = (len(match.group(5)) == 2)
1897
1898        if "task_list" in self.extras:
1899            item = self._task_list_item_re.sub(self._task_list_item_sub, item)
1900
1901        return "<li>%s</li>\n" % item
1902
1903    def _process_list_items(self, list_str):
1904        # Process the contents of a single ordered or unordered list,
1905        # splitting it into individual list items.
1906
1907        # The $g_list_level global keeps track of when we're inside a list.
1908        # Each time we enter a list, we increment it; when we leave a list,
1909        # we decrement. If it's zero, we're not in a list anymore.
1910        #
1911        # We do this because when we're not inside a list, we want to treat
1912        # something like this:
1913        #
1914        #       I recommend upgrading to version
1915        #       8. Oops, now this line is treated
1916        #       as a sub-list.
1917        #
1918        # As a single paragraph, despite the fact that the second line starts
1919        # with a digit-period-space sequence.
1920        #
1921        # Whereas when we're inside a list (or sub-list), that line will be
1922        # treated as the start of a sub-list. What a kludge, huh? This is
1923        # an aspect of Markdown's syntax that's hard to parse perfectly
1924        # without resorting to mind-reading. Perhaps the solution is to
1925        # change the syntax rules such that sub-lists must start with a
1926        # starting cardinal number; e.g. "1." or "a.".
1927        self.list_level += 1
1928        self._last_li_endswith_two_eols = False
1929        list_str = list_str.rstrip('\n') + '\n'
1930        list_str = self._list_item_re.sub(self._list_item_sub, list_str)
1931        self.list_level -= 1
1932        return list_str
1933
1934    def _get_pygments_lexer(self, lexer_name):
1935        try:
1936            from pygments import lexers, util
1937        except ImportError:
1938            return None
1939        try:
1940            return lexers.get_lexer_by_name(lexer_name)
1941        except util.ClassNotFound:
1942            return None
1943
1944    def _color_with_pygments(self, codeblock, lexer, **formatter_opts):
1945        import pygments
1946        import pygments.formatters
1947
1948        class HtmlCodeFormatter(pygments.formatters.HtmlFormatter):
1949            def _wrap_code(self, inner):
1950                """A function for use in a Pygments Formatter which
1951                wraps in <code> tags.
1952                """
1953                yield 0, "<code>"
1954                for tup in inner:
1955                    yield tup
1956                yield 0, "</code>"
1957
1958            def _add_newline(self, inner):
1959                # Add newlines around the inner contents so that _strict_tag_block_re matches the outer div.
1960                yield 0, "\n"
1961                yield from inner
1962                yield 0, "\n"
1963
1964            def wrap(self, source, outfile=None):
1965                """Return the source with a code, pre, and div."""
1966                if outfile is None:
1967                    # pygments >= 2.12
1968                    return self._add_newline(self._wrap_pre(self._wrap_code(source)))
1969                else:
1970                    # pygments < 2.12
1971                    return self._wrap_div(self._add_newline(self._wrap_pre(self._wrap_code(source))))
1972
1973        formatter_opts.setdefault("cssclass", "codehilite")
1974        formatter = HtmlCodeFormatter(**formatter_opts)
1975        return pygments.highlight(codeblock, lexer, formatter)
1976
1977    def _code_block_sub(self, match, is_fenced_code_block=False):
1978        lexer_name = None
1979        if is_fenced_code_block:
1980            lexer_name = match.group(2)
1981            codeblock = match.group(3)
1982            codeblock = codeblock[:-1]  # drop one trailing newline
1983        else:
1984            codeblock = match.group(1)
1985            codeblock = self._outdent(codeblock)
1986            codeblock = self._detab(codeblock)
1987            codeblock = codeblock.lstrip('\n')  # trim leading newlines
1988            codeblock = codeblock.rstrip()      # trim trailing whitespace
1989
1990        # Use pygments only if not using the highlightjs-lang extra
1991        if lexer_name and "highlightjs-lang" not in self.extras:
1992            lexer = self._get_pygments_lexer(lexer_name)
1993            if lexer:
1994                leading_indent = ' '*(len(match.group(1)) - len(match.group(1).lstrip()))
1995                return self._code_block_with_lexer_sub(codeblock, leading_indent, lexer, is_fenced_code_block)
1996
1997        pre_class_str = self._html_class_str_from_tag("pre")
1998
1999        if "highlightjs-lang" in self.extras and lexer_name:
2000            code_class_str = ' class="%s language-%s"' % (lexer_name, lexer_name)
2001        else:
2002            code_class_str = self._html_class_str_from_tag("code")
2003
2004        if is_fenced_code_block:
2005            # Fenced code blocks need to be outdented before encoding, and then reapplied
2006            leading_indent = ' ' * (len(match.group(1)) - len(match.group(1).lstrip()))
2007            if codeblock:
2008                # only run the codeblock through the outdenter if not empty
2009                leading_indent, codeblock = self._uniform_outdent(codeblock, max_outdent=leading_indent)
2010
2011            codeblock = self._encode_code(codeblock)
2012
2013            if lexer_name == 'mermaid' and 'mermaid' in self.extras:
2014                return '\n%s<pre class="mermaid-pre"><div class="mermaid">%s\n</div></pre>\n' % (
2015                    leading_indent, codeblock)
2016
2017            return "\n%s<pre%s><code%s>%s\n</code></pre>\n" % (
2018                leading_indent, pre_class_str, code_class_str, codeblock)
2019        else:
2020            codeblock = self._encode_code(codeblock)
2021
2022            return "\n<pre%s><code%s>%s\n</code></pre>\n" % (
2023                pre_class_str, code_class_str, codeblock)
2024
2025    def _code_block_with_lexer_sub(self, codeblock, leading_indent, lexer, is_fenced_code_block):
2026        if is_fenced_code_block:
2027            formatter_opts = self.extras['fenced-code-blocks'] or {}
2028        else:
2029            formatter_opts = {}
2030
2031        def unhash_code(codeblock):
2032            for key, sanitized in list(self.html_spans.items()):
2033                codeblock = codeblock.replace(key, sanitized)
2034            replacements = [
2035                ("&amp;", "&"),
2036                ("&lt;", "<"),
2037                ("&gt;", ">")
2038            ]
2039            for old, new in replacements:
2040                codeblock = codeblock.replace(old, new)
2041            return codeblock
2042        # remove leading indent from code block
2043        _, codeblock = self._uniform_outdent(codeblock, max_outdent=leading_indent)
2044
2045        codeblock = unhash_code(codeblock)
2046        colored = self._color_with_pygments(codeblock, lexer,
2047                                            **formatter_opts)
2048
2049        # add back the indent to all lines
2050        return "\n%s\n" % self._uniform_indent(colored, leading_indent, True)
2051
2052    def _html_class_str_from_tag(self, tag):
2053        """Get the appropriate ' class="..."' string (note the leading
2054        space), if any, for the given tag.
2055        """
2056        if "html-classes" not in self.extras:
2057            return ""
2058        try:
2059            html_classes_from_tag = self.extras["html-classes"]
2060        except TypeError:
2061            return ""
2062        else:
2063            if isinstance(html_classes_from_tag, dict):
2064                if tag in html_classes_from_tag:
2065                    return ' class="%s"' % html_classes_from_tag[tag]
2066        return ""
2067
2068    def _do_code_blocks(self, text):
2069        """Process Markdown `<pre><code>` blocks."""
2070        code_block_re = re.compile(r'''
2071            (?:\n\n|\A\n?)
2072            (               # $1 = the code block -- one or more lines, starting with a space/tab
2073              (?:
2074                (?:[ ]{%d} | \t)  # Lines must start with a tab or a tab-width of spaces
2075                .*\n+
2076              )+
2077            )
2078            ((?=^[ ]{0,%d}\S)|\Z)   # Lookahead for non-space at line-start, or end of doc
2079            # Lookahead to make sure this block isn't already in a code block.
2080            # Needed when syntax highlighting is being used.
2081            (?!([^<]|<(/?)span)*\</code\>)
2082            ''' % (self.tab_width, self.tab_width),
2083            re.M | re.X)
2084        return code_block_re.sub(self._code_block_sub, text)
2085
2086    _fenced_code_block_re = re.compile(r'''
2087        (?:\n+|\A\n?|(?<=\n))
2088        (^[ \t]*`{3,})\s{0,99}?([\w+-]+)?\s{0,99}?\n  # $1 = opening fence (captured for back-referencing), $2 = optional lang
2089        (.*?)                             # $3 = code block content
2090        \1[ \t]*\n                      # closing fence
2091        ''', re.M | re.X | re.S)
2092
2093    def _fenced_code_block_sub(self, match):
2094        return self._code_block_sub(match, is_fenced_code_block=True)
2095
2096    def _do_fenced_code_blocks(self, text):
2097        """Process ```-fenced unindented code blocks ('fenced-code-blocks' extra)."""
2098        return self._fenced_code_block_re.sub(self._fenced_code_block_sub, text)
2099
2100    # Rules for a code span:
2101    # - backslash escapes are not interpreted in a code span
2102    # - to include one or or a run of more backticks the delimiters must
2103    #   be a longer run of backticks
2104    # - cannot start or end a code span with a backtick; pad with a
2105    #   space and that space will be removed in the emitted HTML
2106    # See `test/tm-cases/escapes.text` for a number of edge-case
2107    # examples.
2108    _code_span_re = re.compile(r'''
2109            (?<!\\)
2110            (`+)        # \1 = Opening run of `
2111            (?!`)       # See Note A test/tm-cases/escapes.text
2112            (.+?)       # \2 = The code block
2113            (?<!`)
2114            \1          # Matching closer
2115            (?!`)
2116        ''', re.X | re.S)
2117
2118    def _code_span_sub(self, match):
2119        c = match.group(2).strip(" \t")
2120        c = self._encode_code(c)
2121        return "<code%s>%s</code>" % (self._html_class_str_from_tag("code"), c)
2122
2123    def _do_code_spans(self, text):
2124        #   *   Backtick quotes are used for <code></code> spans.
2125        #
2126        #   *   You can use multiple backticks as the delimiters if you want to
2127        #       include literal backticks in the code span. So, this input:
2128        #
2129        #         Just type ``foo `bar` baz`` at the prompt.
2130        #
2131        #       Will translate to:
2132        #
2133        #         <p>Just type <code>foo `bar` baz</code> at the prompt.</p>
2134        #
2135        #       There's no arbitrary limit to the number of backticks you
2136        #       can use as delimters. If you need three consecutive backticks
2137        #       in your code, use four for delimiters, etc.
2138        #
2139        #   *   You can use spaces to get literal backticks at the edges:
2140        #
2141        #         ... type `` `bar` `` ...
2142        #
2143        #       Turns to:
2144        #
2145        #         ... type <code>`bar`</code> ...
2146        return self._code_span_re.sub(self._code_span_sub, text)
2147
2148    def _encode_code(self, text):
2149        """Encode/escape certain characters inside Markdown code runs.
2150        The point is that in code, these characters are literals,
2151        and lose their special Markdown meanings.
2152        """
2153        replacements = [
2154            # Encode all ampersands; HTML entities are not
2155            # entities within a Markdown code span.
2156            ('&', '&amp;'),
2157            # Do the angle bracket song and dance:
2158            ('<', '&lt;'),
2159            ('>', '&gt;'),
2160        ]
2161        for before, after in replacements:
2162            text = text.replace(before, after)
2163        hashed = _hash_text(text)
2164        self._code_table[text] = hashed
2165        return hashed
2166
2167    def _wavedrom_block_sub(self, match):
2168        # if this isn't a wavedrom diagram block, exit now
2169        if match.group(2) != 'wavedrom':
2170            return match.string[match.start():match.end()]
2171
2172        # dedent the block for processing
2173        lead_indent, waves = self._uniform_outdent(match.group(3))
2174        # default tags to wrap the wavedrom block in
2175        open_tag, close_tag = '<script type="WaveDrom">\n', '</script>'
2176
2177        # check if the user would prefer to have the SVG embedded directly
2178        if not isinstance(self.extras['wavedrom'], dict):
2179            embed_svg = True
2180        else:
2181            # default behaviour is to embed SVGs
2182            embed_svg = self.extras['wavedrom'].get('prefer_embed_svg', True)
2183
2184        if embed_svg:
2185            try:
2186                import wavedrom
2187                waves = wavedrom.render(waves).tostring()
2188                open_tag, close_tag = '<div>', '\n</div>'
2189            except ImportError:
2190                pass
2191
2192        # hash SVG to prevent <> chars being messed with
2193        self._escape_table[waves] = _hash_text(waves)
2194
2195        return self._uniform_indent(
2196            '\n%s%s%s\n' % (open_tag, self._escape_table[waves], close_tag),
2197            lead_indent, include_empty_lines=True
2198        )
2199
2200    def _do_wavedrom_blocks(self, text):
2201        return self._fenced_code_block_re.sub(self._wavedrom_block_sub, text)
2202
2203    _admonitions = r'admonition|attention|caution|danger|error|hint|important|note|tip|warning'
2204    _admonitions_re = re.compile(r'''
2205        ^(\ *)\.\.\ (%s)::\ *                # $1 leading indent, $2 the admonition
2206        (.*)?                                # $3 admonition title
2207        ((?:\s*\n\1\ {3,}.*)+?)              # $4 admonition body (required)
